> What does wipe_ceph_osds have to do with the certificates? Is there

If wipe_ceph_osds is true, the etcd won't be restored so these certificates as secrets won't exist after restore. There is no point to copy these cert files over as the k8s secrets that these cert files came from are gone, which will cause inconsistency.

kernel-modules/intel-e1000e/centos/build.message: What's with the +1 here?  Just aligning the result with what it was previously ie. a fudge factor?  I notice all the others have a +1 or +2, but drbd has nothing.

that is correct.  I wanted to align PKG_GITREVCOUNT+1 (without OTHER_GITREVCOUNT) to add up to what went before. Most packages had a TIS_PATCH_VER set to or left at '1' at last uprev, rather than setting it back to 0.  One had a TIS_PATCH_VER==2 at last uprev.
And here again, did you check all these?

For each package:
- I found the commit that performed the most recent uprev
- That commit sha becomes the PKG_BASE_SRCREV
- The value of the TIS_PATCH_VER at the time of that commit, is the value I use.  

If they reset to '0', I add nothing
If they reset to '1', or made no change leaving ate a pre-existing value of '1', then I use a +1
If they left it at '2', then I use +2

The resulting build package versions have been verified to be greater than the previous package versions by number of commits in the kernel, plus 1 for this commit.  

One important note... The number of commits on std vs rt kernels is different.  Therefor the revision number for std vs rt build of any given kmod will also differ.

doc/source/afs.rst.message:
The problem isn't specific to pre-1.6.16 and will affect all versions of openafs.

The problem is that Volume Location entries in the database are constructed by the "vos" program and not by the vlserver.  These records do not store DNS hostnames but use the IPv4 address of the fileserver as the canonical server identifier.  In IBM AFS 3.4 there was an introduction of a fileserver UUID to represent multi-homed servers but IBM never finished the conversion of the VLDB from IPv4 based identifiers to UUIDs.  (AuriStorFS 

To this day, OpenAFS vos when creating or updating a volume entry will blindly insert the IPv4 address provided from the command line.  When the volume location entry is received by the vlserver, the vlserver blindly creates a fileserver entry for any IPv4 address received for which there is no matching fileserver entry.

As you concluded, the problem is the hostname to IPv4 address translation where /etc/hosts is taking precedence over the DNS lookups.  The acceptance of DNS hostnames by "vos" is a convenience for humans.   It also accepts IPv4 addresses and doing so will be safe anywhere.

Note that this same problem exists with NAT addresses in case opendev.org ever deploys servers behind a NAT.

You need to decide if you want to pull charts across the cluster-host network or management network.

Regarding the point about using "puppet" base methods; the methods I provided to handle the address lookup and formatting are part of the helm base class (helm/base.py).

There is already a _get_management_address method if you decide to use the management network (example I already provided).  If you want to use the cluster-host network, you can define the following in the helm/base.py class.

def _get_cluster_host_address(self):
    address = self._get_address_by_name(
        constants.CONTROLLER_HOSTNAME,
        constants.NETWORK_TYPE_CLUSTER_HOST)
    return address.address

You can then use it as the following:
self._format_url_address(self._get_cluster_host_address())

There were multiple issues related to overrides.
- The 7743 issue with nested null helm overrides was the major problem; which is now solved picking up helm 3.2.0.

- There is another related to null override CLI input issue; helm v3 has increases validation of inputs. If a chart has keys or values defined, it will not pass validation if you override with "" or null. Many charts that allow override of strings have "{{ X | quote }}, and that actually allows overriding with empty string "", but not null.

Other possible solutions - but I don't like these:
- patch armada chart to add this quote.
- patch helm v3 to disable validation of keys/values

We would normally override the chart node selector/value as:

    node_selector_key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
    node_selector_value: null

But this doesn't work. So we are explicitly setting a node label here for controllers which will match the chart overrides used during ansible bootstrap

Essentially what you are saying is what this is assuming; the 'helm lint' does the dependency check so at least the chart and dependencies are valid at build time.  We assume any dependencies are installed (eg, like helm-toolkit).

This makefile is actually only used for subset of charts.

I made it so that I don't have to add the 'local' repo on the cluster, since we don't use any repo we don't specify, but I needed 'local' during the build phase.

I found was that if any charts self-contain helm-toolkit, they would need requirements.yaml that specify 'local' repo.

I made it so that we can pass the 'helm lint' dependencies, and still serve helm-toolkit and the helm-toolkit is always installed, but can safely remove the dependencies from the package so the cluster does not have to serve this 'local' repo (eg, with ChartMuseum). When configuring helm with v3, we don't configure repos we don't need.

We also do not provision his for helm v3, eg, external repo:
helm repo install stable https://kubernetes-charts.storage.googleapis.com/

For other reviewers, the changes are really minimal, consisting of three hunks. The first is to do with cyborg, where additional tests were added, while the latter is a nova-net removal patch, which dropped the 'firewall_driver' attribute and the need to mock same. Clearly neither should be backported.

+1 you are right that we usually add the NOTE after the Conflicts: list, this might have been a one-off.

FWIW, we usually don't note the reason not to backport the missing conflicting changes if they are obvious like these. Sometimes, there are changes not present on the stable branch that cause conflicts and are mixed in with larger or feature-related changes [that should not be backported], and in that case we selectively cherry pick the pieces we need for the backport and note it in the commit message too.
